title: 108_hr604
content: The "Worker Amnesty and Opportunity Act of 2003" is a new section added to the Immigration and Nationality Act, providing for the adjustment of status for certain undocumented and nonimmigrant aliens. The "Worker Amnesty and Opportunity Act of 2003" added a new section to the Immigration and Nationality Act, allowing the Attorney General to adjust the status of certain undocumented and nonimmigrant aliens to lawful permanent residence if they meet specific requirements. These requirements include maintaining continuous physical presence in the United States for at least 10 years prior to the application submission. The "Worker Amnesty and Opportunity Act of 2003" allows certain aliens to adjust their status to lawful permanent residence if they meet specific qualifications. These qualifications include being sponsored by a labor organization for a job with a worker shortage, being eligible for admission as a student at a higher education institution, or being at least 65 years old. The "Worker Amnesty and Opportunity Act of 2003" allows aliens aged 65 and above to adjust their status to lawful permanent residence without being subject to numerical limitations or certain grounds for exclusion. The "Worker Amnesty and Opportunity Act of 2003" allows aliens to waive certain provisions of section 212(a) for humanitarian purposes, family unity, or public interest, except for specific grounds related to criminals. The "Worker Amnesty and Opportunity Act of 2003" allows aliens to waive certain provisions of section 212(a) for humanitarian purposes, family unity, or public interest, except for specific grounds related to criminals. Paragraphs (2)(C) and (3) are excluded for drug offenses and security grounds, respectively. The Attorney General must temporarily stay exclusion or deportation for applicants with nonfrivolous applications under subsection (a), and provide temporary work authorization. The "Worker Amnesty and Opportunity Act of 2003" allows aliens to waive certain provisions for humanitarian purposes, family unity, or public interest. The Attorney General may provide temporary work authorization for applicants under this section. The "Worker Amnesty and Opportunity Act of 2003" allows aliens to waive certain provisions for humanitarian purposes, family unity, or public interest, including Sec. 210A for alien worker amnesty.
